abstract.para: Amy is a program for playing and analyzing chess games. This handbook covers the installation, configuration and use of Amy.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The author releases Amy in source code only. Precompiled packages are available for FreeBSD and Windows systems. If you want to use Amy on a different operating system (e.g. Linux) or want to enable certain runtime features (e.g. parallel search on multiprocessor systems) you will want to compile Amy yourself.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: Amy uses the Berkeley DB library () software to store the opening book. If you plan to use Amy with an opening book (which is quite likely), you should install the Berkeley DB software prior to compiling Amy. Note that there are several revisions of the Berkeley DB software. Amy is known to work with revision 2 software (tested with versions 2.7.3 and 2.7.7).

section.title: Compiling from source
section.para: Amy uses the autoconf utility to configure operating system dependant details. The standard procedure to build Amy is to issue the commands ./configure && make && make install. This will configure Amy for your platform, compile and install it in /usr/local.

row.entry: Allows you to specify the directory where the Berkeley DB software is installed.

section.title: Using the FreeBSD port
section.para: On FreeBSD there is an Amy port located in /usr/ports/games/amy. To install Amy issue the command cd /usr/ports/games/amy && make install.

section.title: Mac OS X
section.para: Joshua Shriver reported that Amy works 'out of the box' using the usual ./configure and make approach on OS X. He recommends setting CFLAGS to "-O3 -faltivec -mcpu=7450" on a G4 Mac.

section.title: Windows systems
section.para: Thanks to Dann Corbit there are several precompiled versions of Amy for Windows operating systems available on his ftp site.

chapter.title: Configuration

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Several runtime options of Amy can be configured by a resource file. Amy looks for the resource file in the current directory. The resource file is named .amyrc (typically used on Unix/Linux platforms) or Amy.ini (typically used on Windows).

chapter.para:
A typical resource file might look like this:
An Amy resource file
# # Sample .amyrc # # Use 20 MB of hashtables: ht=20m # # Look for tablebases on /space/TB tbpath=/space/TB # # Use 2 processors for parallel search cpu=2 # # Enable game autosaving to allow booklearning autosave=true
Resource file entries
Option Description
autosave
If set to true games played by Amy will be automatically saved. This also enables booklearning.
cpu
Specifies the number of cpu to use for parallel search.
ht
Determines the size of the hashtable. Use the suffixes k to specify the size in kilobytes or m to specify the size in megabyes.
tbpath
Specifies the path were the endgame tablebases are located.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Several features of Amy (e.g. opening book creation, running test suites) are accessible only via the command line interface.

section.title: Creating an opening book
section.para:
Opening books are created or updated using the bookup command. It expects the filename of an PGN file containing one or more games in the PGN format. While parsing the PGN file Amy will output a dot for every hundred games red as a progress indicator.
Creating an opening book White(1): bookup ClassicGames.pgn Parsing PGN file PGN/ClassicGames.pgn. '.'= 100 Games ......................................................................(7000) ...........................................................(12936)
The opening book created is stored in a file name Book.db.

section.title: Flattening an opening book
section.para:
An opening book created from a PGN file will contain many lines which will never be played by Amy since they occur only once in the book. You can remove these lines by flattening the book. This process removes all entries which occur less frequently than some threshold.
Flattening an opening book White(1): flatten 5 Flattening book with threshold 5 Read 183189 entries, wrote 5272 entries
The flatten command produces a file Book2.db. This file can be used instead of the standard opening book Book.db.

section.title: Running test suites
section.para:
You can run a test suite in EPD format with the test command. Typically you will first set a time limit using the level as in the following example:
Running a test suite White(1): level fixed/5 White(1): test EPD/WAC.epd … solved 289 out of 300 (BT2630 = 2597, LCT2 = 10570, BS2830 = 2749) -----------------------------------------------
The output reproduced above is from a real test run on a Dell Inspiron 8200 laptop. Out of the 300 test positions included in the "Win At Chess" test suite Amy solved 289 at 5 seconds per test.
To simplify the evaluation of several standard test suites Amy outputs the scores as calculated by the formulae given for the test suites BT2630, LCT2 and BS2830.

chapter.title: Using a graphical user interface
chapter.para: Amy supports the xboard chess engine interface which is used by xboard and winboard. This includes the feature (since 0.8.3) to inform xboard about the features Amy supports.
To use Amy with xboard use the -fcp like this: xboard -fcp Amy. This example assumes that your PATH variable contains the path to the Amy executable.
